body.p:
Your kindness in forwarding the Feby No. of the Oc-
cident claims my grateful thanks. Its contents at once show the
lamentable state of disunion upon matters in connection with
religion amongst Israelites in America, and sufficiently
exhibit the impracticability of your inserting my commu
nication, up to this time. There may be other reasons
wherefore you think it improper. In the absence of a spe
cial explanation, I can only, and but imperfectly, infer your
views from the course of proceedings. Had the Occident contained
an indication of liberty to proceed in addressing your readers,
this letter would, agreeably to intimation, have inclosed a
year's subscription, as I would not remain under obligation
for worldly favour, when it is avoidable. But since the seeking
of your assistance is, or ought to be, solely in obedience to
spiritual mandates which I dare not disregard, I must learn
in some way, if possible, to what extent your good will or good
opinion towards my business may be counted upon. To purchase
and pay for the Occident while containing nothing in this regard,
would make me no wiser in that respect. If you insert
or discuss my letters, I can then learn your views on them;
if you are so liberal as to continued the transmission of the Oc-
cident without expectation of payment, it must be from some spe
cial consideration; and if you withdraw it, while aware how ne
cessary it is to me to learn by its medium the prospect of the pro
posed assembly. I shall be nonetheless enabled to appreciate your
estimation in my behalf. I am the more anxious to learn, from
practical demonstration, your judgment concerning me be
cause the very extraordinary situation in which I am placed
overwhelms my weak and unsettled mind with the dread of
misconceiving my duty. By carefully comparing ideas with
the differently affected yet interested and able to discover the
truth, I may test the soundness of conceptions, which, without

some corroboration, must incur distrust. The inclosed $1.00 I beg you to
accept on act. Of some No's of the O. formerly sent me at New York; or if you
would decline it on that ground, let it be to defray postage which may occur.

One would think that, while so desirous of bringing my views
before some authority in Israel, I should greatly rejoice in the pros
pect of an Assembly and their doings, as now before us; but reflec
tion upon the issue of my formal application to the Beth Din in
New York as I reported it to you, teaches me to expect little from
any body of men who may be actuated by a dread of compromi
sing their character for wisdom. Yet as our excellent friend Mr.
Noot, Dr. Salomon and another passed a resolution that my repre
sentations were worthy of attention and ought to be investigated &
reported on by two or more persons of the first distinction for learning
devotion, character and understanding, I must not fail, if the venerable
in Israel come together, to apply for the relection of a suitable
committee, who after free and full communication, shall formally de
clare their views of the matter submitted to their consideration.
If you would do me the greatest kindness, if you would become
nobly instrumental in relieving the deepest anxieties of a mind
that seeks to ascertain its duties in order to their discharge, you
have but to forward by every means in your power my honest
aim to bring the teachings of this extraordinary state of mind
fairly and fully before the Jewish public for their consideration
To my private desires, it would seem to be of little importance how
men should entertain these disclosures provided the decision could
be final. What makes me anxious is that whilst my thoughts
are absorbed as they are and must be for the present, my
wife and children are suffering for the want of attention
which is their due, and which I cannot give them, as my
faculties are insufficient under such a distraction. It appears
that I must either become an active, however humble, servant
of Israel, or, obtaining some conscientious satisfaction that will

authorize the withdrawal of my attention from the subject, devote
the more energy to pursuits of a private nature. Could I but learn
by a reasonable decision of the judgments of others upon these un
common views, that they must pass for either erroneous or im
practicable, gladly would I hail the liberty to apply to the cares
labours and pleasures of my family and farm; gladly would
I strive to join in the common and selfish pursuits of life:
but while the best and soundest with whom I am enabled to con
verse, approve and even reverence my views, while those who
censure are evidently inconsiderate in their examinations, while
it is not only what has been manifested to an excited percep
tion; but a calm examination of all current events of every sort
leads to a like conclusion,—and while, to my utter amazement,
the whole seems indicated in the prophecies of old, how can
I doubt the evidence that presents itself to one purpose in
so many different ways, when that purpose is but the es
tablishment of a government recognizing, what sound sense re
quires, as a leading principle, the accountability of man to his
maker?

I do not appeal to you for the sake of Israel, for you
are sufficiently bound already to that consideration. I plead
not for the good of mankind in general, for you comprehend
as well as I the connection between the Restoration and the spread
of intelligence, uprightness and peace. But as the Lord so
orders that even in our highest aims we are influenced more
or less by private regards; as He kindly grants the grateful
stimulus of selfish satisfaction in our most sacred aspira
tions; and as we are humble men, of limited capacities, yet
generous and sympathetic feelings; I will endeavour to elicit
your sensibilities in my favour by appealing to your knowledge
as a spiritual teacher and your heart as my brother man, in
regard to my private position as a religious individual. I have

two children, sweet little girls, the eldest but two years of age, whom
I would bring up in the knowledge and fear of the Lord. I am
an Israelite in faith, if I know what it is to be an Israelite—
namely, to live under a perfect sense of accountability to God,
aiming in all things to do that which is right in His view; there
fore necessarily adopting the high wisdom of inspiration in the
formation of rules of conduct, and devoutly seeking self-improvement
and the general good in associating with others disposed to wor
ship and serve God in purity and truth. I would say with pi
ous Joshua “as for me and my house, we will serve the Lord.”—
but how? Shall I take my family to a Christian Church to hear
that belief in absurdity is the vital condition of happiness hereafter.
Shall we cultivate ignorance, and avoid participating in any estab
lished form of worship—to the effect that ? be heaped upon
my innocents as being trained to error and infidelity? Or shall
I crave admission from a Jewish congregation, to join in prayer
for the advent of a Messiah, instead of returning thanks for
the appointment of a special and most distinguished service—
shall I enter such a congregation on condition of allegiance
to all the existing Laws and customs, when I do not intend
to obey them, and the very perception which makes me desire
religious association, also assures me that many of those u
sages and institutions are now needless, some of them wrong,
and that it is my especial calling to be humbly instru
mental in their reform? Which shall I adopt, of these er
roneous courses? Or rather what can I do but prayerfully
trust in the Divine Goodness to relieve my perplexities
in due time, and strive by every means to bring my views
to be compared with those of others whose superior attainments
entitle them to respect and confidence, while their vital wants, the
proper longing of their souls, must stimulate them to discover and
approve and establish the truth if truth it be, which I have to disclose

I can see no other course to be right; and therefore do I thus beseech assistance.
For some half year more, according to a remarkable impression, must I
remain in this uncertainty and trouble: if by that time there be not a
clearing up of difficulties I shall have cause to respect a radi
cal error in these sublime perceptions.

You once wrote me the story of Shaman and Hillel and one who
would become a Jew with the condition of being made High Priest.
The case is no parallel to mine; I desire no distinction—far less the
accountability of power. I have lived forty years without at any time
being led by political ambition or religious zeal. True heroes, in my
view, are those who, keeping within their means, devoutly apply themselves
to the common duties of life. What devotion I have exercised may have
been far surpassed in the experience of many religious minds amongst
us. It is prophecy a startling glimpse of the natural course of events,
and their causes, showing the unfailing means established for the pro
duction of good, which it only devolves upon men to observe and employ,
that this impels me to so strange a course. What should I care
for worldly appearances? What is it to me if my conduct seem
unaccountable and absurd to those who know not its motives?
I must only hasten to bring matters to a crisis, to attain facil
ities for efficient action, or freedom to forbear from futile endeavours.
Will you not help me? Do I ask more than naturally pertains between
man and man? You admit that the developments of the day indicate
the present as a fit time for rising in behalf of Israel. Let it then
be decided whether I may lawfully and properly undertake to act
in this good cause in conjunction with the chosen servants of the
most High. If you say that I am not a Jew, let me ask, was
Abraham other, in that respect, than I am? Or did Moses
submit to a string of rabbinical exactions? Supposing he had,
it would be no rule for me. The useless part of these observances
must be done away. The general forms of Jewish worship are as
grand in effect as venerable from antiquity. But many spe
cial institutions which were founded in good reason from the ex
igency of circumstances, have now no effect but a detrimental in

fluence. Long have the people groaned under these absurd incum
brances; and what is worse, forsaken the faith of their fathers,
to escape form such annoying accomplishments. In assisting to re
tain these evils, you become answerable for their natural conse
quences. It needs but to prune away such exhausting, useless
and unsightly branches—it needs but to exhibit the pure princi
ples of religious faith under a rational and modest form,
and the tree of righteousness will flourish, take root in the earth,
unfold its blossoms to the world, give fragrance to the airs
of heaven, and yield reproductive fruit spreading abroad
for the delight and shade and comfort of regenerate man.
The pure Jewish faith, the simple belief in omnipresent Deity, to whom
we are strictly accountable, must become the religion of the world,
not because it is written that the Lord declared so by His prophet
not because it bears a fascinating show to the imagination
for it does not, but because it is the truth, and men are becom
ing sufficiently enlightened and considerate to distinguish sim
ple truth from seductive falsehood. Let the Jew once stand
a free man in his own country, and the brawling nations will
let fall their weapons in astonishment, acknowledge in their heart
the truth of revelation, and incline to turn from the errors of their
ways. Then may peace and reason and kindness prevail; for
men, become more reflective, will see it for their interests to
cultivate good dispositions. The best minds among gentiles will
associate themselves with the already established Jews. Dif
ferent races will thus intermingle without violence to law
or custom. By this means a large portion of subsequent generations
will be born under the ameliorating influence of those natural
laws hereby increase of vigor is given to cross breeds.
The ancient blood of Israel serving as a basis, a foreign admix
ture to a certain extent, will benefit the race, promoting the
development of its energies, and marking the Jews, as a people,

with such physical and mental superiority, as must inevitably
render them masters amongst mankind. The use they will make
of power, must depend, in a great measure, upon the purity of
their religious principles: and it therefore devolves the more
fearfully upon us, if it please God to employ our weak hands
in this His good work, to aim at the highest perfection in
whatever rules and practices we may ? to establish.

It is observable from the records of history, as well as re
searches into nature, that the chief means whereby a race ar
rives at a high standard of perfection is the copulation of pa
rentage bringing together somewhat dissimilar constitutions:
yet, when one of the parties is highly cultivated, extreme oppo
sition does not answer the purpose: thus the refined white
and the barbarous negro or Indian cannot be intermixture
bring improvement to the superior; and the effect is ques
tionable even upon the inferior race. In a mind of much
refinement is established a deep repugnance to the coarse
ness of ignorance and vulgarity; for it is decreed that
when such excellence is once attained, it ought not to be
thrown away: yet the two sexes are established, that, by
continental intermixture of different constitutions, offspring
may arise inheriting the general characteristics, which
it is our business to establish in ourselves, of both
parents; and not the particular defects which may be
beyond our control, of either. Intermarriages therefore are
predicated upon a positive, though not extreme, dissimilar
ity of constitution in the parties, while they are as necessarily
influence by similarity of sentiments, habits and pursuits.
It is then plain that the restored Jews, together with those no
ble

-ble-minded from other nations, who will dare to cast off the
fetters of error and prejudice, must operate under every
beneficial influence to produce the most powerful and highly
gifted race of which we can conceive, precisely in accord-
ance with undeviating and well known laws of nature. There
is no record of a people becoming, either on the whole or at any
particular time, great and powerful in all respects, whose
physical excellence is not to be traced directly to the inter-
mingling of different races or dissimilar tribes. Thus, under
ordinary circumstances, a conquest? however lamentable to the
humbled people becomes the means, under God, of health
and blessing to posterity. If a nation could but comprehend
their duty, if a government would only provide, by ade-
quate and strictly natural means; for the development
of every inherent energy of man, and for preserving the
excellence of the race when once attained, that people could
never be subdued; for, granting by way of argument, the
existence of abler nations, their ability would abundantly
supply their wants by easier and more profitable measures
than war against the unoffending, who would be supported
by a sense of justice, and ruled by a regard for the most
High, that would require conquest and extermination to be
made synonimous terms. Even the corrupted Jews of old were
but beaten and dispersed, and not subdued like other nations,
to resign their peculiar laws and coalesce with the victors. They
were conquered as men—not as Jews. Persecution, in its ut-
most violence could only cripple, but never tame their true
spirit of adoration. It has still angered upon earth and
groaned in agony unto the Lord of hosts,—and lo! he com-
-eth to relieve. Most faithfully yours—
